message_1: What is the time dilation factor between the twin astronauts who travel in space for 5 years at a speed of 0.8c (where c is the speed of light), and their twin sibling who remains on the Earth? How much younger will the traveling twin appear to be when they return to Earth?
message_2:
To calculate the time dilation factor, we can use the Lorentz factor formula:

γ = 1 / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where γ is the Lorentz factor (time dilation factor), v is the velocity of the moving twin (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

γ = 1 / sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)
γ = 1 / sqrt(1 - 0.64)
γ = 1 / sqrt(0.36)
γ = 1 / 0.6
γ ≈ 1.6667

The time dilation factor is approximately 1.6667.

Now, let's find out how much younger the traveling twin will appear to be when they return to Earth. Since the traveling twin experiences time dilation, their time will pass slower compared to the twin on Earth. We can calculate the time experienced by the traveling twin using the following formula:

t_traveling_twin = t_earth_twin / γ

where t_traveling_twin is the time experienced by the traveling twin, t_earth_twin is the time experienced by the twin on Earth (5 years), and γ is the time dilation factor.

t_traveling_twin = 5 years / 1.6667
t_traveling_twin ≈ 3 years

The traveling twin will experience approximately 3 years of time during their journey.

Now, to find out how much younger the traveling twin will appear to be when they return to Earth, we can subtract the time experienced by the traveling twin from the time experienced by the twin on Earth:

Age difference = t_earth_twin - t_traveling_twin
Age difference = 5 years - 3 years
Age difference = 2 years

The traveling twin will appear to be 2 years younger than their twin sibling who remained on Earth when they return.
